title: Sahak II Bagratuni
text:
Sahak II Bagratuni (<a href="Armenian%20language">Armenian</a>: Սահակ Բ Բագրատունի), was an <a href="Armenians">Armenian</a> nobleman from the <a href="Bagratuni%20Dynasty">Bagratuni Dynasty</a>. He served as the <a href="marzban">marzban</a> of <a href="Persian%20Armenia">Persian Armenia</a> briefly in 482.
Biography.
Sahak II was the son of <a href="Tirots%20I%20Bagratuni">Tirots I Bagratuni</a>, an Armenian "<a href="aspet">aspet</a>". When Tirots died in 451, Sahak II was given the aspet title. In 475, the <a href="Mamikonian">Mamikonian</a> princess <a href="Saint%20Shushanik">Shushanik</a>, was murdered by her husband Prince <a href="Varsken">Varsken</a>, who was a convert to <a href="Zoroastrianism">Zoroastrianism</a>, and was related to the Mihran family. The reason for this murder was because she had refused to convert to Zoroastrianism and wanted to stay <a href="Christianity">Christian</a>. Varsken, because of his actions was in 482 executed by <a href="Vakhtang%20I%20of%20Iberia">Vakhtang I</a>, king of <a href="Caucasian%20Iberia">Iberia</a>. The <a href="Sasanian">Sasanian</a> <a href="shah">shah</a> <a href="Peroz%20I">Peroz I</a> shortly sent an army to punish Vakhtang for intervening. However, Vakhtang was joined by the Armenians, and a revolt broke out in Armenia, led by <a href="Vahan%20I%20Mamikonian">Vahan I Mamikonian</a> and Sahak II.
Vahan and Sahak managed to defeat the marzban <a href="Adhur%20Gushnasp">Adhur Gushnasp</a>, and Sahak was shortly declared by Vahan and the other Armenians as the marzban of Armenia. However, in 482, Peroz sent an army under <a href="Shapur%20Mihran">Shapur Mihran</a>, which defeated the Armenian rebels, killing Sahak. Vahan then fled to the mountains, while Shapur regained control of Armenia. Sahak had a son named <a href="Spandiat">Spandiat</a>, who was given the title of aspet after his death.
